headline: Supporters of Ukraine rally, pray in Parma and Cleveland
author: Lisa Ryan
sentences:
pic.twitter.com/Vu8Nntz9r6
— Governor Mike DeWine (@GovMikeDeWine) February 26, 2022
The Russian Cultural Garden of Cleveland also declared support for the Ukrainian people, saying on Facebook that leaders will "take down the flag of the country that started the war against (the) independent State of Ukraine."
Ukraine's flag will also soon fly at the Ohio Statehouse and Governor's Residence to further show support for those under attack in Ukraine and for Ohio's Ukrainian population.
Rob Portman plans to speak at the Sunday rally about the ongoing invasion in Ukraine and what he thinks needs to be done in Congress, according to a press release.
As Russia invades Ukraine about 5,000 miles away from Cleveland, supporters of Ukraine and its people rallied in Northeast Ohio this weekend.
BLUE-YELLOW | we stand in solidarity with Ukraine and all those seeking peace amidst the violence wrought by war.
Mike DeWine spoke on Sunday morning at a church service at St. Andrew Ukrainian Catholic Church in Parma.
I have declared Sunday, February 27, 2022, a Day of Prayer in Ohio honoring the people of Ukraine.
He told the nation on NBC's "Meet the Press" that he'd be there to show solidarity for Ukraine.
Many tweeted blue and yellow hearts, the colors of the Ukrainian flag, to show their support.
The Cleveland suburb is home to Ohio's largest population of Ukranians with more than 4,000.
Pictures show Terminal Tower lit up in blue and yellow to also show support.
On Saturday, people gathered at Public Square in downtown Cleveland.
